question:
(a) Draw a well-labelled diagram to show the intreral structure of the earth

(b) Describe the main features of any two of the parts shown in (a) above.
answer:
Core: Innermost layer, about 3476km wide all round, consists largely of iron and nickel, divisible into inner and outer core, found in a molten state, reservoir of minerals to the other zones.

Mantle: middle layer, surrounds the core, about 2897km thick, composed of very dense rocks, rocks are rich in olivine basalt.

Crust: Lies above the mantle, outer layer, consists of granitic and basaltic rocks, varies in thickness from place to place , divisible into 2-sial and sima, forms soil, sustains life.

question:
Write explanatory notes on the formation of any two of the following:

(a) Waterfalls

(b) Deltas

(c) Inselbergs
answer:
(a) Waterfall: occurs at the upper course of a river, occurs as a result of erosion, a resistant hard rock is left to form an obstacle, the protruding obstacle now causes the river to rumble down from a higher to lower ground, may be formed when a river plunges down the edge of a plateau, when a fault-line scarp lies across a river.

(b) Delta:

  • A feature of the lower course of a river/or at the mouth of a river.
  • Formed as a result of deposition of sediments at the lower course of a river.
  • Rate of deposition faster than rate of removal of silt at the coast slow rate of flow of the river.
  • Here the river divides into several channels called distributaries shallow depth of water along the coast.
  • The distributaries cut through the deposits before finally flowing into the sea

(c) Inselbergs: are isolated mountains formed as a result of intrusion of magma into the earth's crust and resisted erosion when all other surroundings were eroded, exposed by differential erosions by water or wind.

question:
(a) Define the term mass wasting

(b) Describe two types of mass wasting

(c) State three effects of mass wasting
answer:
(a) Definition - movement of weathered material (debris) under the force of gravity usually down slope

(b) Types; 
- Soil creep
- Solifluction
- Landslide, Slumping, etc.

(i) Soil Creep;

  • It occurs in areas of deep chemical weathering on moderate slopes.
  • It is caused by rain drop impact and thaw and freeze of ice.
  • It is also caused by expansion and contraction of soil aggregates.
  • It is responsible for down slope tilting of trees on slopes and the movement is slow and not noticeable.

Identifying mass wasting - Description

(ii) Solifluction

  • It occurs in temperate and sub-polar regions *Its soil is usually saturated
  • Its soil and rock fragments move downslope.
  • Freezing and thawing alternate to supply the kinetic energy required for the debris transfer.
  • It is frozen creep.
  • Movement is not restricted to definite channels.

Identifying mass wasting - Description
(iii) Landslide:

  • Various forms such as shrimping, debris fall involves dry mass of earth's debris rock shrimping.
  • Movement of large rock debris
  • Over underlying weak rock
  • Movement is in succession
  • Small rock debris moving down slope at a time resulting in a number of step like terracettess, e.g. Mississippi valley.

Identifying mass wasting - Description
(c) Effects

  • Loss of farmlands
  • Displacement of settlements *Disruption of transportation network
  • Tilting of electric poles and telegraph poles
  • Damming of a river *Loss of soil fertility

question:
(a) Highlight the characteristics of the equatorial rain-forest

(b) Outline four ways in which climate influences the equatorial rain-forest
answer:
(a) Characteristics of the Equatorial Rain-forest:

(i) Some of hot humid areas around the equator, e.g. Amazon Basin West African Coastlands, Malaysia, Indonesia, Zaire Basins.

(ii) The trees are big and robust

(iii) They should be up to 60m in height

(iv) They have broad leaves

(v) Evergreen forest

(vi) The branches interlock, forming canopies which are in layers

(vii) Sunlight hardly reaches the ground

(viii) Numerous undergrowth

(ix) Three distinct layers are noticed, namely:
(a) upper
(b) middle
(c) lower

(x) Has the greatest number of plant species.

(xi) Different species of p!ants could be identified in small areas, example include: Obeche, Iroko, Walnut, Ebony, Mahogany, Epiphytes and Linnen fern.

(b) (i) Influence of climate on the equatorial rain forest

(ii) Heavy rainfall -supports numerous plant growth

(iii) High temperature supports the growth of trees, the mean (sea level) temperature of about 27°C with a range of 1° - 3°C enhances the growth of various species of plants.

(iv) Annual rainfall of above 2000mm supports the growth of luxuriant trees

(v) Rainfall throughout the year makes the forest evergreen, hence it is called evergreen forest.

question:
(a) What is environmental pollution?

(b) Describe four causes of environmental pollution

(c) Outline three ways in which environmental pollution can be controlled
answer:
(a) Environmental pollution is the introduction of harmful substances or unhealthy condition to the environment.

(b) Causes of Environmental Pollution:

(i) Discharge of chemical pollutants into the atmosphere

(ii) Accelerated industrialisation which leads to increased emission of industrial and toxic wastes

(iii) Emissions from aircraft and vehicles

(iv) Atomic bomb testing and the use of atomic energy in industries release radioactive substances into the atmosphere.

(v) Burning of bushes, coal and firewood

(vi) Poor sewage disposal/refuse disposal

(vii) Mineral working and oil spillage

(viii) Use of artificial fertilizers, insecticides, pesticides and herbicides in agriculture

(ix) Use of big loudspeakers produces noise pollution

(x) Use of big industrial machines produces heat that causes thermal pollution.

(c) Control of Environmental Pollution:

(i) Government legislation to check industrial emissions into the atmosphere.

(ii) Factories and motor cars should have anti-pollution devices

(iii) Observation of anti-pollution measures

(iv) Removal of poisonous and harmful chemicals from industrial wastes before being discharged into the rivers and seas.

(v) Improved methods of sewage disposal

(vi) Greater care in handling petroleum products

(vii) Use of machines that are more efficient in fuel combustion

(viii) Turning down of loudspeakers to approved noise level

(ix) Environmental impact assessment to be carried out before any project is executed

(xi) Strict adherence tc Land Use plannings

(xii) Public enlightenment, e.g. seminar, education.

question:
(a) Define Ecosystem

(b) Describe four ways in which man has interfered with the ecosystem

(c) Outline three consequences of man's interference with the ecosystem.
answer:
(a) Ecosystem is the community of plants and animals living together in harmony and interacting with their physical environment

(b) Ways in which man has interfered with the ecosystem:

(i) Modification of weather and climate through cloud seeding, deforestation

(ii) Agricultural activities

(iii) Fishing and hunting

(iv) Industrialisation/ Urbanization

(v) Reclamation to create terrestrial ecosystem in place of aquatic bush burning.

(vi) Mining

(c) Consequences of man's interference with the ecosystem

(i) Soil erosion resulting from overgrazing

(ii) Destruction/depletion of forest resources

(iii) Extinction of animal species due to excessive hunting and over fishing

(iv) Pollution of air/water, e.t.c. through emission of gases and introduction of industrial effluents.

(v) Damage :o ozone layer with its attending danger-skin cancer destruction of bacteria, damage to ocean life and reduction in crop yield.

(vi) Alteration of weather and climate, e.g. cloud seeding.

question:
(a) With specific examples; explain the terms:
(i) light industry (ii) heavy industry

(b) Highlight four factors that limit industrial development in tropical Africa.
answer:
(a) (i) Light industries are industries that produce light goods which are made for consumption. They usually ma-use of materials which have already been partially processed. Examples are leather industry, food industry, textile  industry, printing and publishing and household goods.

(ii) Heavy industries are industries that manufacture heavy capital goods, such as ship, machinery, chemicals, etc. Examples are iron and steel industry, heavy engineering works, etc.

(b) Factors that limit industrial development in Tropical Africa:

(i) Inadequate skilled manpower

(ii) Low level of education and training

(iii) Small market

(iv) Inadequate infrastructure

(v) Shortage of raw materials

(vi) Inadequate capital

(vii) Inadequate power supply

(viii) Mismanagement

(ix) Political instability

(x) Restrictive industrial and administrative policies

(xi) Preference for foreign goods/competition with foreign goods.

question:
(a) Give any three reasons each for the
(i) high volume of trade between Nigeria and the U.S.A.
(ii) low volume of trade between Nigeria and Ghana

(b) Suggest any four ways of improving trade between Nigeria and other West African countries.
answer:
(a)(i) Reasons for high volume of trade between Nigeria and the USA.:

(a) The two countries have different types of climate and different agricultural products

(b) USA has high technology and therefore concentrates on manufacturing while Nigeria does not manufacture enough

(c) Nigeria needs agricultural machinery which are manufactured in USA.

(d) The raw materials produced in Nigeria are needed in factories in USA

(e) Nigeria has large markets for some goods manufactured in USA, e.g. computer, electronics, etc.

(ii) Reasons for low volume. of trade between Nigeria and Ghana:

(a) Similar ecological characteristics, hence the products are similar

(b) With the same level of technology, their products are identical.

(c) Poorly developed communication link

(d) High taste for goods of European origin

(e) High tariff

(f) Different currencies

(g) Political instability

(b) Ways of improving trade between Nigeria and West African countries:

(i) Specialization in production

(ii) Use of the same currency

(iii) Improved relationship between the countries

(iv) Improvement of communication network

(v) Removal of tariff barriers/investment promotion

(vi) Economic freedom from old colonial masters.

question:
(a) On a sketch map of Nigeria, locate and name:
(i) the Chad Basin and the Western Highlands; (ii) one important river in one of the regions (iii) one important town in each region.

(b) State three ways in which the relief and drainage of the Chad Basin differ from those of the Western Highlands.

(c) Highlight three problems of development in the Chad Basin.
answer:
(b) Differences in relief and drainage between Chad Basin and Western Highlands:

(a) Chad Basin is a.lowland region while Western Highlands is a highland region

(b) Average elevation for Chad Basin is 45-60m while that of Western Highland is 300-600m

(c) Western Highlands is underlain by metamorphic rocks of basement complex while Chad Basin has sedimentary rocks.

(d) Chad Basin has inland drainage while rivers of the Western Highlands drain into the Atlantic ocean and the Niger valley.

(e) On the western highlands rivers flow southwards or northwards while in the Chad Basin, the rivers flow north-east wards.

(f) Areas around Lake Chad are swampy while swamps do not exist in the Western Highlands

(g) In the Chad Basin river include Hadeja, Yedseram, Komadugu-Gana, Yobe, etc while on the westerm highlands they include Osun, Ogun, Moslu, Ossa.

(c) Problems of development in the Chad Basin

(i) Harsh climate

(ii) Wind erosion

(iii) Pest and diseases

(iv) Scanty rainfall (65cm) leads to low agricultural production

(v) Poor transportation

(vi) Desert encroachment

(viii) Sparsity of population.

question:
(a) On a sketch map of Africa, locate and name:
(i) two fold mountain areas (ii) two important rivers north of the equator (iii) two ocean currents: one warm; one cold (iv) the Tropic of Cancer and Capricorn.

(b) Explain how one of the ocean currents in (a)(iii) above affect the climate and v 3getation of the adjacent coastlands.
answer:
(b) Effects of warm or cold ocean current on climate and vegetation: Warm Current:

 (i) Raises the temperature of adjacent coastland

(ii) Raises the temperature of surface waters

(iii) Resulting in high rainfall

(iv) High rainfall and high temperature give rise to dense vegetation

(v) Makes the on-shore wind to carry more moisture inland

Cold  Current

(i) Lower the temperature of adjacent coastland

(ii) Lowers the temperature of surface waters

(iii) On shore wind form fog

(iv) Low rainfall/arid condition gives rise to desert vegetation

(v) Resulting in scanty rainfall and arid conditions

(vi) Responsible for the formation of Namib Desert (cold Benguella Current).

question:
Write a geographical account of irrigation agriculture in the Niger Basin under the following headings:

(a) Areas (b) Methods (c) Crops (d) Problems (e) Solutions
answer:
Irrigation Agriculture in the Niger Basin.
(a) Areas:

(i) Inland delta of the Niger (Mali)

(ii) Jebba or Bacita area of Nigeria

(iii) Sokoto-Rima Valley

(b) Method:
(i) Basin or flood irrigation

(ii) Perennial (Dams and barrages)irrigation

(iii)Pump

(iv) The shaduf

(v) Manual

(vi) Sprinkler

(c) Crops: cotton, wheat, sorghum, vegetable, millet, rice, sugarcane, barley, 
maize, onions groundnuts, etc.

(d) Problems:

(a) High capital outlay in dam construction

(b) Silting of dam by sand deposition

(c) Salinity of soil due to excessive evaporation

(d) Seasonality of rivers

(e) Periodic flooding of farmlands

(f) Growth of aquatic weeds

(g) Water-borne diseases

(h) Collapse of dam

(i) Displacement of settlement

(j) Erosion associated with surface irrigation.

(e) Solutions:

(i) Improved methods of irrigation should be adopted

(ii) Continuous dredging of river channels

(iii) Elements containing acid, added to soil

(iv) Storage of enough water during floods

(v) Bigger channels made to contain flood water

(vi) Continuous clearing of water weeds.

(viii) Resettlement of displaced people.

(ix) Adequate medical care provided to check the special water-borne diseases

(x) Improved technology in construction of dams.
